title: Ennerdale Forest Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: Bob Jenkins / Moss Dub
images.caption: Moss Dub. A small, shallow pool, a hidden gem in the forest.

images.title: Gareth Browning / Ennerdale Forest
images.caption: Ennerdale forest occupies one of the most remote valleys in the Lake District. This view from below Bowness Knott gives a fantastic panoramic impression of this wild valley. The mountain peak of Pillar in the middle foreground and Ennerdale Water to the right of the picture add drama to the scene.

images.title: David Brown / River Liza, Ennerdale
images.caption: A view of the River Liza which flows through the forest

images.title: Tom Richardson / Forestry track, Ennerdale
images.caption: Forestry track,. Taken near bridge over Low Beck

images.title: Bob Jenkins / Ford over Woundell Beck
images.caption: Ford over Woundell Beck in the Cumbrian civil parish of Ennerdale and Kinniside. Progress along this side of Ennerdale used to be difficult due to having to cross several large becks; the Forestry Commission works have greatly helped.

images.title: Footbridge over the Liza by Richard Law, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Footbridge over the Liza

images.title: David Brown / Bridge over the River Liza
images.caption: Bridge over the River Liza

description: Enjoy miles of traffic free cycling and walking trails in this super forest in the Lake District National Park. The route starts at the Bowness Knott car park next to the beautiful Ennerdale Water. You then head east into the forest along the lakeside path. After leaving the lake behind the track follows the River Liza into the forest to Ash Crag before returning along the south side of the river. The forest tracks are quite uneven in places so a mountain bike is required for cyclists. The views of Ennerdale valley are fabulous with some of the highest and best-known fells in Cumbria forming a spectacular backdrop - Great Gable, Green Gable, Brandreth, High Crag, Steeple and Pillar are all visible on the route. Just to the south of the forest is Pillar, the eighth highest mountain in the eighth highest mountain in the Lake District. You can climb to the peak from the forest via the striking Pillar Rock.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: For more walking ideas in the area see the Lake District Walks page.

display_address: Bowness Knott Car Park, Smithy Beck Trail, Ennerdale and Kinniside, Cumberland, England, CA23 3AU, United Kingdom
